comment: I viewed the full course, and in my opinion until SDEs it was amazing, but I feel that when they started from Martingale Pricing it stopped to be a scientific frame to be instead a belief system, using somehow math as the argument for justify a betting system instead of using it as a tool for reduce uncertainty: as example, it is all based on the Expected Value gived by the Mean Value, but since distributions are skewed (LogNormal if geometric Brownian motions is assumed, like in Black-Scholes eqn.), you have more chance of finding values below the average than on it (mode<median<mean), this is why I hardly believe that the No-Arbitrage theorem is structered in the right framework, even if the math is right: is like having the optimal theory for playing checkers, but unfortunately the game we play is chess, it is the same gameboard, but the results surely don't going to fulfill your "expectations".
